awd_titl_txt: A Multi-District Collaboration to Develop Justice-Focused Computational Thinking Pathways for Middle School English Language Arts
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is funded in whole or in part under the American Rescue Plan Act of 2021 (Public Law 117-2).

Often computational thinking (CT) and computer science (CS) instruction is approached as an isolated or extracurricular activity, limiting exposure for many students. In many cases, these activities focus on specific STEM-related domains such as robotics, where girls and students of color are underrepresented and marginalized. As a result, school-based CS classes and programs often continue to marginalize girls and students of color. Teaching CT/CS as part of literacy instruction offers one solution to engage historically underrepresented students in both subjects. The project instructional materials will be developed to build on and value students' diverse literacies, cultural resources, interests, and identities.  The project will explore the impact of this instruction on historically underrepresented groups in CS (specifically, female and Black students) and advances knowledge on transforming CS education and practices in building diverse partnerships. The project's long-term goal includes creating innovative justice-focused curricula and related teacher professional development (PD) materials for integrating CT/CS into middle school literacy instruction. The outcomes from this grant will support STEM and literacy educators and curriculum developers to rethink methods of integrating CT/CS across disciplines.  Additionally, the project will develop strategies to help build CS identities among those who feel least connected to it, such as girls and students of color. 

This Research to Practice Partnership (RPP) project establishes a network that includes four school districts in Pennsylvania, middle school educators, University of Pittsburgh faculty, and a regional educational support center (Allegheny Intermediate Unit) collaborating to develop a justice-focused CT/CS curriculum for Middle School English Language Arts (ELA). The project goals include the design and development of justice-focused CT/CS curricular materials for middle school ELA classes focused on increasing computational identity, CT/CS knowledge, and digital empowerment among students historically underrepresented in CS, specifically, female and Black students. Additionally, the curricular materials will be iteratively revised and tested in a subset of classrooms, assessing students' responses to the materials and sense of belonging in CS through surveys, assessments of learning goals, and STEM career identity instruments.  Finally, the project will strive to equip underrepresented middle school students with the knowledge, skills, identities, and agency to succeed in high school computer science courses and beyond. In this project, the partner school districts all face the "problem of practice" of ensuring culturally relevant CS instruction that is meaningful to students and can be embedded into the existing curriculum to ensure equitable CS access. The first stage of the project will focus on partnership-building, knowledge-building, and co-designing preliminary research questions. The second stage will focus on rapid co-designing CS/ELA curriculum materials and PD for teachers, testing the materials in classrooms, and assessing students' responses to the materials. An external evaluation of the RPP will be conducted at the end of phase 2. This project is supported by the CS for All: Research and RPPs program.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In today's rapidly evolving digital landscape, integrating Computer Science (CS) and Computational Thinking (CT) into justice-oriented English Language Arts (ELA) curriculum presents a crucial opportunity. Although the importance of this integration is widely acknowledged, implementing it successfully remains a complex challenge. This CS4ALL Small RPP project focuses on researching and addressing the support needs of ELA teachers and school personnel in planning and delivering CT/CS instruction. In collaboration with ten middle school teachers, a school district professional network liaison, and researchers, the project unfolded in two phases: Phase 1: Collaborative Focus Negotiation and Phase Two: Iterative Co-Design and Testing, with the following objectives:

  1. Establishing a Research-Practice Partnership (RPP) team comprised of Pitt Education faculty, Allegheny Intermediate Unit (AIU) staff, and middle school ELA educators from four Pittsburgh, PA area school districts.
  2. Co-designing justice-focused Computational Thinking (CT)/Computer Science (CS) curriculum materials for middle school ELA classes, aiming to enhance computational identity, CT/CS knowledge, and digital empowerment among historically underrepresented CS students, particularly female and Black students.
  3. Iteratively refining the curricular materials and testing them in select classrooms, evaluating student responses through surveys, assessments, and STEM career identity measures.

 

Our approach emphasized building partnerships across the university, schools, district, community, and an education support network to create a robust CT/CS curriculum for middle school English Language Arts.

 

Intellectual Merit

 

Supporting ELA Teachers and School Personnel

The partnership involved collaboration among educators, administrators, and research partners, revealing specific support needs for ELA teachers and principals in navigating CT/CS integration effectively.

  1. Development of CT/CS Content Knowledge: Both teachers and principals expressed a strong desire for robust CT/CS content knowledge. ELA teachers, in particular, highlighted the need to enhance their understanding of CT/CS concepts compared to their STEM counterparts, emphasizing the importance of targeted professional development.
  2. Engagement in a Community of Learners: Collaboration emerged as a recurring theme, with educators valuing the co-design of curricula with experts from diverse disciplines. This collaborative effort created a community of learners dedicated to successful CT/CS integration, fostering innovative teaching practices.
  3. Context-Specific Implementation Support: Teachers stressed the necessity of school-based support mechanisms to address challenges in implementing CT/CS-infused curricula, including collaborative planning, co-teaching, and instructional coaching. Principals emphasized the role of professional development in enhancing their capacity to support teachers in this endeavor.

 

Justice-Oriented CT/CS Integration in Middle School

Embedding justice-oriented CT/CS instruction in middle schools is a commendable yet challenging goal, necessitating educators' adaptability to students' needs and contexts effectively.

  1. The Role of the RPP Model: The Research-Practice Partnership (RPP) model employed aligned with effective RPP characteristics: problems of practice, sustainability, deepening partnerships and community, mutualism, and the production of original research. While community and mutualism thrived, sustainability and addressing problems of practice faced challenges due to teacher turnover, highlighting the importance of continuity and onboarding for new partners.
  2. Professional Learning Networks: Throughout the project, various training and professional development opportunities equipped educators and stakeholders with the necessary skills and knowledge for successful CT/CS integration. This included CT/CS content knowledge, equity considerations, and model lessons including Peer Collaboration: Collaborating with peers across disciplines was central to curriculum implementation success, especially in justice-oriented instruction; Adaptive Expertise: Teachers demonstrated adaptability by tailoring curricular materials to align with students' prior knowledge and unique backgrounds, emphasizing the importance of adaptive expertise; Flexible Professional Learning: Professional learning accommodated online and face-to-face formats, adapting in complexity and content to meet teachers' evolving needs.

 

Broader Impacts

This research extends beyond ELA, offering interdisciplinary insights. Successful CT/CS instruction relies on peer collaboration, adaptive expertise, and flexible professional learning. Collaborating across disciplines was crucial, showcasing the importance of adaptive expertise in tailoring instruction to students' backgrounds. This project advances our understanding of support requirements for ELA teachers and school personnel in CT/CS instruction and highlights the broader impact of justice-oriented CT/CS integration across disciplines. The insights gained from this innovative RPP model will inform future efforts to bridge the gap between traditional education and the evolving CT/CS landscape, shaping the future of education as we prepare students for a tech-driven world.

 

This CS4ALL Small RPP project created the path towards meaningful integration of Computer Science and Computational Thinking into justice-oriented English Language Arts curriculum. By addressing the specific support needs of ELA teachers and school personnel, fostering collaboration, and adapting instruction to students' unique contexts, we have not only enhanced the quality of CT/CS education but also paved the way for broader interdisciplinary impacts. As we move forward, the lessons learned from this endeavor will continue to inform educational practices, ensuring that all students, regardless of background, can access the transformative power of computational thinking and computer science, thus shaping a more inclusive and future.
